issues.text: Whether the nomination paper of respondent No. 1 was validly filed, including whether it was presented on 20th January 1967, accompanied by a copy of the electoral roll, and a receipt for security deposit under s.34 RPA

anchor.surface_text: No deposit as required by s. 34 of the Act was made in time and, further still, respondent No. 1 was not qualified... It was alleged that, despite all these defects. respondent No. 1 was declared elected unopposed

issues.text: Whether respondent No. 1 was disqualified under Article 173(a) read with s.36(2)(a) RPA and Election Commission notification for failure to make and subscribe oath/affirmation before the scrutiny date or before the Returning Officer of Shiggaon constituency

issues.text: Whether corrupt practices of bribery, undue influence, and obtaining assistance from the Returning Officer (a government servant) were committed with the consent of respondent No. 1 to procure withdrawal of appellant No. 1's candidature

anchor.surface_text: We may next take up the question of the charges of corrupt practices alleged to have been committed with the consent of respondent No. 1 relating to bribery, undue influence and obtaining of assistance, from a Government servant, viz., the Returning Officer.

issues.text: Whether the nomination paper of respondent No. 1 was actually presented after the deadline, without required accompaniments (electoral roll copy and deposit receipt)

holdings.text: The High Court was incorrect in upholding the affirmation made by respondent No. 1 on the date of scrutiny (21st January 1967); the oath or affirmation must be made before the date fixed for scrutiny as per s.36(2)(a) RPA and Pashupati Nath Singh precedent.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, this Court has clearly held that the effect of the provision contained in s. 36 2 a of the Act is that the oath or affirmation must be before the date fixed for scrutiny, so that the candidate possesses the qualification under Art. 173 a of the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent from Pashupati Nath Singh; new ground allowed despite not raised in High Court.

holdings.text: One oath or affirmation made before an authorized Returning Officer for one constituency prior to scrutiny suffices to qualify the candidate under Article 173(a) for candidature in any constituency.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that this submission must be accepted. The purpose of Art. 173 a is to ensure that any person, who wants to be a member of a Legislature of a State, must bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of Art.173(a); once disqualification removed by one proper oath, no need for repetition across constituencies; supported by textual reading and facts elicited in cross-exam.

holdings.text: Election Commission notification requires oath before Returning Officer of that particular constituency from which the candidate seeks election.

anchor.surface_text: In using the expression that Constituency, it is clear that the intention of the Election Commission was that, the affirmation must be made before the Returning Officer of that particular constituency from which the candidate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation rejecting broader reading; 'that constituency' means specific one.

holdings.text: No corrupt practices (bribery, undue influence, obtaining assistance from Returning Officer) committed with consent of respondent No. 1; petitioners' version false as disproved by circumstances and unreliable witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The story that has been put forward on behalf of the appellants has already been described by us in detail when giving the facts of the case. The appellants alleged that they were taken to the house of R.W. 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict standard of proof for corrupt practices; petitioners' witnesses interested/unreliable; circumstantial evidence (newspapers, admissions, conduct) disproves confinement/bribery story.

holdings.text: No adverse inference against respondent No. 1 for not examining Patil Puttappa; High Court justified in rejecting application to summon him as court witness under O.16 R.14 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: on the failure of respondent No. 1 to examine Patil Puttappa, an adverse inference should be drawn against him. the appellants moved an application to the Court to take his evidence-under 0.16, r. 14

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioners failed initial burden; evidence already disproved case; distinguished precedents (Chenna Reddy, Seshadri) requiring credible prima facie case first; purity of election not demanding where case false.

holdings.text: Nomination paper of respondent No. 1 validly presented on 20th January 1967, accompanied by electoral roll copy and security deposit receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, we may take notice of the three further allegations that the nomination paper of respondent No. 1 was, in fact, not presented, on 20th January, 1967 secondly, that, if at all it was presented,

holdings.text: Withdrawal form of appellant No. 1 presented by him personally; no assistance from RO in faking it.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 has, however, clearly stated that this withdrawal form of appellant No. 1 was presented by appellant No. 1 himself, and we find no reason to disbelieve his evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: RO evidence accepted given falsity of petitioners' overall version; no witness to contradict.

precedents.citation: Pashupati Nath Singh v. Harihar Prasad Singh.  1

anchor.surface_text: Pashupati Nath Singh v. Harihar Prasad Singh.  1  In that case, this Court has clearly held that the effect of the provision companytained in s. 3 6  2   a  of the Act is that the oath or affirmation must be before the date fixed for scrutiny, so that the candidate possesses the qualification under Art. 173  a  of the Constitution on the whole of the day on which the scrutiny of numberination has to take place.

precedents.case_name: Pashupati Nath Singh v Harihar Prasad Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: the effect of the provision contained in s. 36(2)(a) of the Act is that the oath or affirmation must be before the date fixed for scrutiny, so that the candidate possesses the qualification under Art. 173(a) of the Constitution on the whole of the day on which the scrutiny of nomination has to take place
precedents.cited_holding: oath or affirmation must be before the date fixed for scrutiny

anchor.surface_text: Pashupati Nath Singhs case 1 , there is numberjustification for debarring respondent No. 1 from putting forward the alternative case on the basis of the affirmations made at Bagalkot and Hospet.

precedents.case_name: Pashupati Nath Singh v Harihar Prasad Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: basis for new ground on oath timing

precedents.citation: Nani Gopal Swami v. Abdul Hamid-Choudhury and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Patil, in this connection, relied on a decision of the Assam High Court in Nani Gopal Swami v. Abdul Hamid-Choudhury and Another 1  to urge that, though the burden, of proof in the present case in respect of the companyrupt practices was initially on the appellants, respondent No. 1 was number altogether absolved from his responsibility to assist the Court by producing the best evidence available after the appellants had tendered their own evidence.

precedents.case_name: Nani Gopal Swami v Abdul Hamid Choudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: respondent not absolved from responsibility to produce best evidence even if burden on petitioner

precedents.citation: Dr. M. Chenna Reddy v. V. Ramachandra Rao and Another 2

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made to a recent decision of this Court in Dr. M. Chenna Reddy v. V. Ramachandra Rao and Another 2  where the number- examination of the best person who companyld have companye and given evidence in favour of the candidate who was charged with companyrupt practice was taken as one of the circumstances justifying the belief of witnesses examined to prove the companyrupt practice on behalf of the opposite party.

precedents.case_name: Dr M Chenna Reddy v V Ramachandra Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: non-examination of best witness as circumstance supporting proof of corrupt practice after petitioner's evidence accepted

precedents.citation: R. M. Seshadri v. G. Vasantha Pai 3

anchor.surface_text: The third case, to which reference was made, is also a recent decision of this Court in R. M. Seshadri v. G. Vasantha Pai 3 , where this Court dealt with the question of the exercise of power by the Court trying the election petition to examine a witness as companyrt witness.

precedents.case_name: R M Seshadri v G Vasantha Pai
precedents.cited_proposition: court power to summon court witness if ends of justice require; policy to investigate corrupt practices thoroughly
precedents.cited_holding: trial judge properly exercised power to summon court witnesses

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, we may cite further remarks made by this Court in the case of R. M. Seshadri 1  to the following effect- Although we would say that the trial should be at arms length and the Court should number really enter into the dispute as a third party, but it is number to be understood that the Court never has the power to summon a witness or to call for a document which would throw light upon the matter, particularly of companyrupt practice which is alleged and is being sought to be proved.

precedents.case_name: R M Seshadri v G Vasantha Pai
precedents.cited_proposition: court has power to summon witness or document for corrupt practice allegations if necessary to find author
